text: References the contents of an external USD file into a branch of the existing scene graph tree, or removes/replaces existing references.
Referencing takes the tree in the referenced file and "grafts" it onto a branch in the current tree.
For example, if you start with this tred:

lamp
    base
    bulb
    shade
    socket
    switch
Then after referncing the file, the tree will look like this
) are composed together (with overlapping property values decided by opinion strength), but the prim keeps the name of the original referencing prim.
of a file. If you reference a file and don’t specify a specific prim in the file, you get the file’s "default primitive".)
When you reference in content, you must specify a prim in the referenced file (
in the example above), and that prim cannot be the root (
). So when you're creating a file that is meant to be referenced in by other layers, you should organize the contents under a single root primitive.
Referencing is useful to graft smaller individual assets into a larger scene. In particular,
referencing is the only way to load the same layer file more than once at different locations
. (Because sublayering works on the entire tree, sublayering the same file more than once would have no effect.)
If the prim you want to reference onto already has an existing reference, the new reference will be composed
parameter for how to clear existing references before adding a new one.
The "target" that gets referenced onto a primitive in the scene graph tree is often in an external file, however this node can also reference a prim in the output of another LOP node.
to the scene graph path at which the referenced prim should be attached.
to the file path of the USD file to reference in.
pop-up menu if you want to choose the prim in the external file to load in.
set to "Reference automatically chosen primitive". If you want to import a specific prim, change
to "Reference specific primitive" and enter the prim path in
Reference a prim in an external file
Connect the LOP node containing the stage you want to reference to this node’s multi-input.
If you have multiple inputs connected to this node’s multi-input:
to a scene graph path to import from the same prim in all inputs, or write an expression which is evaluated from each input connected to this node’s multi-input. In the expression, you can use the
local variable for the current input index (starting at
). (Remember that in string parameters, you must enclose expressions in backticks.)

Next to each input in the table below the parameters, click in the Reference Primitive Path and enter the scene graph path of the prim you want to reference in from that input. If an input has a Reference Path in the table, it ignores the value of the
For a single addition, you can set the
Reference a prim from the output of a LOP node
to the scene graph path at which the referenced prim should be attached.
to "Reference from first input", "Inherits from first input", or "Specialize from first input", depending on the type of composition you want.
to the scene graph path of the prim you want to reference in.
Reference another prim in the scene graph tree in the first input
to the scene graph path of the prim that currently has a reference you want to block.
to the scene graph path of the prim with the reference you want to remove.
Set the parameters to specify the reference you want to remove. For example, if you want to remove a reference to the file

Scene graph path where the referenced branch will be attached. The referenced prim will be overlayed onto this prim, and the referenced prim’s descendants will become this prim’s descendants. If this prim doesn’t exist, the node will create it.
doesn’t exist, this node will create it. If it has to create the prim, it will set it to have this
doesn’t exist, this node will create it. If it has to create the prim, it will give any intermediate prims it has to create this type.
. This saves memory if you reference the same branch into multiple places, but makes the descendants of the referenced prim not editable.
The type of composition arc to create to the referenced prim.
Reference in a prim from an external USD file.
Reference in a prim from an external USD file as a
Reference in a prim from one of the nodes connected to this node’s multi-input.
Reference in a prim from one of the nodes connected to this node’s multi-input as a
Reference in another prim from the scene graph tree in the first input.
Create an "inherits" composition arc to another prim from the scene graph tree (in the first input).
Creates a "specializes" composition arc to another prim from the scene graph tree (in the first input).
If the reference is to an external file, this controls what the node does if the referenced file does not exist.
The node errors, preventing cooking the rest of the network.
The node shows a warning, then passes through the first input unchanged.
The node silently ignores the missing file, and passes through the first input unchanged.
Author the reference to the sublayer even if it currently doesn’t exist. This node and the following nodes will probably print warnings from the USD libraries about missing files.
Allow Missing Files on the Stage
If you set this to a value other than "No pre-opertation", the node clears existing references on the node.
Do not clear existing references on the prim at
Clear any additions or removals to the list of references on this prim made
This is not a non-destructive USD edit
. It’s more like undo-ing any changes from previous nodes that are currently "pending" in the active layer.
Clear Reference Edits in Active Layer

Authors an override of the specified reference type which masks all existing references on this primitive, regardless of the layer in which they were authored. This provides a blank slate so that only the references specified by this node will remain.
How new references added by this node interact with existing references on the prim at

When editing references on a primitive, you are really making edits to a list. These edits are expressed as adding to the beginning or the end of the list created by composing all weaker layers, or by explicitly removing certain items from the list.
Make new references stronger than any references from lower layers, and stronger than any previous "prepend" edits in the currently active layer.
Add as Strongest References in Prepend List
Make new references stronger than any references from lower layers, but weaker than any previous "prepend" edits in the currently active layer.
Add as Weakest References in Prepend List
Make new references weaker than any references from lower layers, but stronger than any previous "append" edits in the currently active layer.
Add as Strongest References in Append List
Make new references weaker than any references from lower layers, and weaker than any previous edits in the currently active layer.
Add as Weakest References in Append List
The layers or primitives referenced by this node are removed from the list of references on the destination primitive rather that being added.
Because this removal is expressed as a list edit, you can selectively remove specific layers from the list of references, no matter what layer authored the original reference.
This node can add multiple references to the specified prim, however the reference type, and operation will be the same for all additions.
Number of Files (in File-based modes and primary input modes)
Perform the reference in this instance of the multi-parm.
is "Reference files" or "Payload files", the file path to the file to reference in.
is "Reference files" or "Payload files", this controls which prim to import from the external file. When
is "from first input" or "from multi-input", you should set this to "Reference specific primitive" (the other options are usually pointless in that case).
If the referenced file has a
set, use that. If there is no default prim, use the first Xform prim at the root. If there is no Xform prim at the root, use the first root prim of any type.

set, use that. If not, display a warning on this node and ignore this instance of the multi-parm.

is "Reference specific primitive", this is the scene graph path to the prim to reference in.

to "Reference automatically chosen primitive" or "Reference default primitive".)
Offsets all time samples from the file. You can use this to re-time animations in the references file.
Scales all time samples from the file. You can use this to re-time animations in the references file.
Click to reload the contents of all files imported by this node.

title: Reference
summary: References the contents of an external USD file into a branch of the existing scene graph tree, or removes/replaces existing references.
